What a wonderful classic movie to find on dvd!  It seems to be an edited for television version, but great all the same...(you can tell where the commercials came in).  They just don't show enjoyable old movies like this on tv any more. A Louis Jourdan gem with a very young Joan Collins in it!
the story was good. it kept me thinking what was going to happen next. the actors were good and believable. picture quality of this dvd is good as well.

This early 1950's rendition of Boccaccio's late Medieval anthology of romantic stories is a special cinematic offering.  While the film does not attempt to convey the literary work's bawdy details and less than idealistic depiction of human nature, it surely delivers a memorable and entertaining movie blessed with beautiful cinematography and excellent acting by the likes of Louis Jourdan, Joan Fontaine, and a young Joan Collins.  The film presents three separate stories utilizing the same cast members and does so successfully thanks to superlative direction.  This movie provides a nostalgic glimpse of cinema in an era when even provocative topics were treated innocently.  Not only does the film create for the viewer a window on the world of European life in the waning decades of the Middle Ages, it also serves as an excellent example of moviemaking and all of its' colorful legacy and inherent challenges in the middle of the 20th century.

This movie really stunk. It must be public domain because all these public domain el cheapo tape companies carried this title and the print was completely out of focus, like a bad bootleg. Even apart from the atrocious quality of the image the film looked mediocre at best and Joan didn't photograph as well in color. Stick with Joan and Louis (Jourdan) in the wonderful black and white classic Letter to an Unknown Woman.

Caveat emptor!
The wonderful Joan Fontaine rules in this romantic tales based in Rennaisance Italy. It's a must see!!!!!!!!!1
Considering its age, the quality was much better than I was expecting.

I have loved this movie for decades!  I found it on TV in the 80's on the weekend and used to look for it to be on again and again.  Louis Jourdan and Joan Fontaine are great in the three stories and it's fun to see Joan Collins so young!

This version I just purchased on DVD also came with an online version I was just able to download onto my iPod!  What a pleasant surprise!  Now I can watch this classic any time and any place I want!
